ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: It was a very good assessment of the links between journalism and policy-making.
Gained very useful knowledge about the field of journalism (its evolution and current state), developed oral presentation skills and research/synthesis skills.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think the discussions were good but could have been improved by spreading out the reading more so we could focus on specific ideas more. I liked how we linked the topics in class to real world issues.

The weekly reading responses were useful in helping us think through the readings before class discussions. Lectures and guided discussions were interesting. The readings were very useful in understanding course material and some (like "All the Truth is Out") were fascinating.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Sure! It's a good seminar on a really interesting subject.

I would recommend this course to another student, especially if they want to learn more about the field of journalism from an instructor who is an expert in the field. The fact that there is no exam (grades based on responses, papers and a presentation) was not only less anxiety-inducing, but also extremely helpful since it allowed me to focus on truly grasping and thinking through and beyond the class materials (not learning simply to memorize for an exam).
